column6: Organizational details
column7: QBE Insurance Group Limited (QBE) was founded in Townsville, Queensland 1886. It is now headquartered in Sydney and listed on the Australian Securities Exchange.

column6: Entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting
column7: The scope of QBE sustainability reporting and data metrics includes critical performance data from the subsidiary companies in North America, International, and Australia Pacific.

column6: Reporting period, frequency, and contact point
column7: This Report covers the period 1 JanuaryÃ¢ÂÂ31 December 2023 and should be read in conjunction with the Sustainability Data Book and the Annual Reports.

column6: Restatements of information
column7: In 2021, QBE committed to Net Zero 2030 for scope 1 and 2 emissions for our global operations from a 2019 baseline year. This target was extended to include material scope 3 emissions in 2022.
column24: Location from QBE 2023 Sustainability Data Book

column6: External assurance
column13: Full limited assurance provides users of the financial statements with a moderate confidence level in the reliability and accuracy of the information presented. The level of assurance provided is limited compared to a full audit, where auditors provide reasonable assurance that the financial statements are free from material misstatement.

column6: External assurance
column8: ASAE 3000 Assurance Engagements Other than Audits or Reviews of Historical Financial Information
column13: The full title of ASAE 3000 is "Assurance Engagements Other than Audits or Reviews of Historical Financial Information." This standard provides guidelines for assurance engagements other than audits or reviews of historical financial information.

column6: External assurance
column8: ASAE 3410 Assurance Engagements on Greenhouse Gas Statements
column13: The full title of ASAE 3410 is "Assurance Engagements on Greenhouse Gas Statements." This standard provides guidelines for assurance practitioners when conducting assurance engagements, specifically on greenhouse gas (GHG) statements.

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column7: QBE is an international insurer and reinsurer offering a diverse portfolio of commercial, casualty, and specialty products as well as personal line and risk management solutions. Our diverse product portfolio includes property, motor, crop, public and product liability, professional indemnity, workers' compensation, energy, marine and aviation.

column6: Employees
column7: In FY23, QBE and our controlled subsidiary companies employed 13,479 people worldwide.
column24: Location from QBE 2023 Sustainability Data Book in DB Focus Area 2

column6: Workers who are not employees
Governance structure and composition
column7: At the date of this Report, the Board has eleven directors, nine of whom are independent, one group chief executive officer, and one independent Chair.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column13: The Board Governance & Nomination Committee assists the Board with succession planning and selecting non-executive directors and the Group Chief Executive Officer so that the Board has the necessary range of skills, knowledge, and experience to be effective. The Committee also reviews succession plans for Group Executive Committee (GEC) members who report to the Group Chief Executive Officer.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column13: For non-executive directors and the Group Chief Executive Officer, a formal selection and appointment process is undertaken by the Governance & Nomination Committee. The Governance & Nomination Committee comprises four non-executive directors of the Board and is chaired by Mike Wilkins.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column8: External consultants related to nomination and selection
column13: External consultants may be employed where necessary to search for prospective candidates for non-executive director and GEC roles. Candidates are assessed against the required skills, knowledge, experience, qualifications, and attributes, ensuring their alignment with QBE's DNA.

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: Mr. Michael Wilkins, AO, is the chairman of QBE.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column13: The Board of Directors plays a crucial role in setting the Company's overall strategic direction and ensuring that social, ethical, and environmental considerations are integrated into the Company's mission, vision, and long-term objectives. They may establish policies, monitor performance, and oversee risk management related to these areas.
column24: Location from QBE 2023 Sustainability Data Book https://www.qbe.com/sustainability/our-approach-to-sustainability/sustainability-governance-management

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column13: The Board of Directors is responsible for the Group's risk management framework. Board members review and approve the organization's risk management policies and procedures, monitor critical risks, and receive regular reports on the effectiveness of risk management activities from management and internal audit.
column24: Location from QBE 2023 Sustainability Data Book https://www.qbe.com/sustainability/our-approach-to-sustainability/sustainability-governance-management

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column13: The sustainability committee comprises senior representatives from across the Group who manage sustainability issues and are responsible for delivering on the actions associated with QBE's Sustainability Scorecard and commitments. These representatives come from business units that include risk, underwriting, finance, impact, responsible investments, people, and culture.
column24: Location from QBE 2023 Sustainability Data Book https://www.qbe.com/sustainability/our-approach-to-sustainability/sustainability-governance-management

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column13: The ESG MG reports to the Executive Management Board (EMB) of QBE European Operations (EO) and the QBE Europe Management Committee (QEMC) of the Board of QBE Europe SA/NV. The ESG Risk Committee assists the ERC in identifying and managing ESG risks across the Group, including relevant controls, metrics, scenario analysis, and Environmental and Social Risk Framework oversight.\t
column24: Location from QBE 2023 Sustainability Data Book https://www.qbe.com/sustainability/our-approach-to-sustainability/sustainability-governance-management

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column13: The Group Sustainability team, led by the Group Head of Sustainability, reports to the Group Executive Corporate Affairs and Sustainability, a GEC member. The team drives sustainability across our business, including developing and implementing our sustainability strategy and developing an enterprise-wide action plan to drive progress on our Sustainability Commitments.
column24: Location from QBE 2023 Sustainability Data Book https://www.qbe.com/sustainability/our-approach-to-sustainability/sustainability-governance-management

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column8: Group Underwriting Sustainability and Governance team
column13: QBE has a dedicated Group Underwriting Sustainability and Governance team led by the Group Head of Underwriting Governance, Sustainability, and Standards, who reports to the Group Chief Underwriting Officer, a GEC member. Underwriting also participates in various sustainability-related committees, including the ESG Risk Committee.
column24: Location from QBE 2023 Sustainability Data Book https://www.qbe.com/sustainability/our-approach-to-sustainability/sustainability-governance-management

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column8: Group Impact and Responsible Investments team
column13: QBE has a dedicated Group Impact and Responsible Investments (IRI) team that reports to the Group Chief Investment Officer (CIO) and the Group Chief Financial Officer, a GEC member. The IRI team seeks to integrate sustainability considerations into our investment decision-making process and lead our net zero investment initiatives.
column24: Location from QBE 2023 Sustainability Data Book https://www.qbe.com/sustainability/our-approach-to-sustainability/sustainability-governance-management

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column13: The Group Finance team has commenced an important enabling role in developing an information governance framework for reporting sustainability metrics included in the Sustainability Data Book and the associated assurance activities. This team also supports the measurement of insurance-associated emissions of the underwriting portfolio.\t
column24: Location from QBE 2023 Sustainability Data Book https://www.qbe.com/sustainability/our-approach-to-sustainability/sustainability-governance-management

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column13: The Group ESG Risk team, led by the Head of ESG Risk, reports to the Chief Enterprise Risk Officer. The team also supports the review of referrals related to the Environmental & Social Risk Framework and the modern slavery risk assessment process, where relevant.
column24: Location from QBE 2023 Sustainability Data Book https://www.qbe.com/sustainability/our-approach-to-sustainability/sustainability-governance-management

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column13: The Board is a senior executive responsible for developing, implementing, and overseeing the Company's sustainability strategy. This role may report directly to the CEO or another top executive and work closely with other senior leaders in operations, finance, marketing, and human resources.
column24: Location from QBE 2023 Sustainability Data Book https://www.qbe.com/sustainability/our-approach-to-sustainability/sustainability-governance-management

column6: Conflict of interest
column13: Directors are required to advise the Board on an ongoing basis of any interest they believe could conflict with QBE's interests. If a potential conflict arises, the director concerned may choose not to, or the Board may decide that they should not receive documents or participate in Board discussions while the matter is being considered.

column6: Communication of critical concerns
column13: A Code of Conduct is a set of guidelines, principles, and rules that outline expected behaviour and ethical standards for individuals within an organization. It serves as a framework for guiding decision-making and actions, promoting integrity, transparency, and accountability, and fostering a positive organizational culture.

column6: Communication of critical concerns
column13: A Consequence Management Policy outlines the procedures, principles, and guidelines for managing and addressing employee misconduct, violations of company policies, or breaches of ethical standards. It serves as a framework for promoting ethical behaviour, deterring misconduct, and ensuring consistency, fairness, and transparency in managing organisational disciplinary matters.

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column7: The Chair ensures that the Board functions as an effective and cohesive group. The Chair works closely with the Group Chief Executive Officer to determine QBE's strategic direction and establish high standards of governance and leadership.

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column13: The Board has a skills matrix covering each director's range of competencies and experience. When the need for a new director is identified, the required experience and competencies of the new director are considered in the context of this matrix and any gaps that may exist.

column6: Remuneration policies
column13: A Remuneration Framework, or a Compensation Framework, is an organization's structured approach to design, implement, and manage employee compensation and benefits programs. It outlines the principles, policies, and practices that govern how employees are rewarded for their organizational contributions.

column6: Remuneration policies
column13: QBE's Remuneration Principles outline the guiding principles and policies that govern how the Company compensates its employees. By adhering to these Remuneration Principles, QBE aims to attract, motivate, and retain talented employees, drive high performance and accountability, and create value for shareholders and stakeholders while maintaining a solid commitment to fairness, transparency, and compliance.

column6: Remuneration policies
column13: Trading in QBE ordinary shares is generally permitted outside of designated closed periods. QBE's Securities Trading Policy states that non-executive directors and other designated employees must notify nominated people within the Group of any intended share transaction.

column6: Remuneration policies
column13: The MSR ensures executives build their shareholding to have significant exposure to QBE's share price. Under the MSR, a minimum of three times fixed remuneration for the Group CEO (one-and-a-half times for other executive KMP) will be maintained as long as the executive KMP remains at QBE.
